learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an introductory level awareness of the current state of welfare of key groups of people in Australian society.
Demonstrate a preliminary understanding of the key concepts and theories underpinning the analysis of social welfare.
Evaluate your own and others' knowledge and attitudes towards the groups of people studied.
Articulate an interest in and commitment to the welfare of Australians and to the wellbeing of Australian society.
Demonstrate introductory analytical skills (deductive reasoning, argument development,and critical analysis).
Demonstrate a capacity for self-directed learning.
Demonstrate the capacity to read and use references, prepare essays, and participate in class discussions.

assessments.task_description:
This description is only a summary of the task. For full details and guidance, including the marking rubric, please refer to the course Learn UQ (Blackboard) site: Assessment section/Assessment 1.

Reflective Essay: Experiences of Welfare

The task is to write a 650 word essay reflecting on 1) your experience of receiving welfare; and 2) how your experience is similar or different from those of your peers.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit through Turnitin in the Folder, Assessment; Subfolder, Assessment 1 of the SWSP1011 Blackboard site. Use a docx format not pdf.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2: Welfare Policy and Family Experiences
assessments.task_description:
This description is only a summary of the task. For full details and guidance, including the marking rubric, please refer to the course Learn UQ (Blackboard) site: Assessment section/Assessment 2.

Welfare Policy and Family Experiences

In your first assignment you wrote about how you and your peers received and experienced Australian welfare.  This assignment moves to consider the policy context for individuals and families that you may engage with as social workers. The aim of this assignment is for you to consider the family's circumstances and how policies/programs interact with their lives.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit through Turnitin in the Folder, Assessment; Subfolder, Assessment 2 of the SWSP1011 Blackboard site. Use a docx format not pdf.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam involves two parts. Part 1 includes multiple choice questions. Part 2 includes short essay questions. The exam covers the contents of the entire course including the lecture material, tutorial material, and readings. We will discuss the exam in Week 13's classes. 

The exam will be held on campus, and will be closed book. The time and place of the exam is administered by the University Examinations Unit. Students can only bring in their student card (compulsory) and writing materials.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1 - Poverty in Australia

We start tutorials in Week 1. Enrol in a tutorial if have not done so.

Tutorials assume you will have worked through the lecture material and the reading/s. The tutorials are designed for discussion and critical thinking. You will be able to ask questions and clarify concepts from the lectures. It is also an opportunity to meet your colleagues.
